The student conferences are regarded,everywhere as summing up
the year's work of the Student
Christian Associations of North
America. Every year increases the
number of college men who bear
witness to the value of these gatherings. In the interest of a larger
and more cosmopolitan gathering,
it has been decided to unite the Linwood Conference of Ohio and the
Pocono Conference of Pennsylvania.
The desirability of securing a more
satisfactory site has also helped to
determine this union. The new
gathering will he known as The
'Atlantic Student ConferMiddle'
ence, and will meet on the shores
of the beautiful Eagles-Mere Lake,
on the crest of the mountains north
of Williamsport, Pa., from June 14
to 23, 1912. No more desirable
o.r beautiful spot for a student conference could be desired. The lake
is a mile and a half long and one
mile wide, affording unsurpassed
opportunities for bathing on the
clean, evenly sloping white sand
beach and for most delightful rowing and canoeing.
The Student Conference is not a
purposeless outing. The forenoons
will be devoted to study of religious
and social conditions here and
abroad. The last period of each
forenoon will be the platform addresses, and a glance at the following list of speakers will convince
anyone of the strength and value
of the Eagles-Mere platform addresses. If there were nothing to
be gained from attending the conference but the privilege of hearing
these men, the conference would be
invaluable to every thinking collegeman. A partial list of those who
will address the conference is as follows:
Robert E. Speer—Mr. Speer is
a graduate of Princeton. He is
now secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian
Church. For many years he has
been a popular speaker at student
conferences in America, and his
journeys to other lands have made
him well known in some of the important student centers of the world.
Harry E. Fosdick—Mr. Fosdick
has been a popular speaker at summer conferences for some years, and
his invitations to fill college pulpits
have outrun the possibilities of acceptance. Those who were here
three years ago at Hopkins, remember what forceful addresses Mr.
Fosdick gave us.

Tackling the hardest and longest
schedule of any Hopkins athletic
team on record, the baseball nine
this spring made a poor start, losing
the first six games, but finished
splendidly, winning the last four.
The team developed form slowly,
becoming an effective machine late
in April; then the State colleges
were walloped beautifully. Two big
games, those with Harvard, on April
13, and with the Chinese on May
15, were prevented by rain.

John Gardner Huck, of the class
of 1912, was elected captain of next
year's 'Varsity lacrosse team, at a
meeting held after the captain's
dinner last Tuesday night. Johnny
Huck is one of the most experienced players at Hopkins, as Ile
has played at Mount Washington
for five years, three with the juniors
and two with the regulars. Although he has - been out for the
Hopkins team, he has never played
a full season until this year, when
he was one of the mainstays of the
defence.
The retiring captain, "Bill" Gail,
gave the team a most delightful
and delicious dinner at his home on
Park avenue. The time was passed,
between courses, in songs and
cheers, as usual, and after dinner,
the "old guard" was on hand with
the usual quantity of speech.
Pitts, the stage-coach, was the
orator par excellence, his funeral
oration at the death of Raleigh being received with great applause.

After a week of hard matches,
the Hopkins Tennis Tournament is
completed, except for the last match
in the singles. In the finals, Sears,
an undergraduate, will fight it out
with Dubray, of the Medical School.
It is diffiC1.1-it to say who will win,
as the playing style of the two
players is directly opposite; while
Dubray is by far the more brilliant,
Sears plays a steady, persistent
game, which literally wears out an
opponent. Both players have had
to beat good men to get to the final
round. It took Dubrav three sets
to defeat both Getz and Crawford,
While Sears, in three of the four
matches he has played, namely,
those with Hatch, Huck, and Belt,
had to extend himself to three sets
also.
Sears' match with Belt in the
semi-finals Saturday afternoon was
desperately fought by both players.
The first set Belt lost 6 to 3, being
entirely off his game. In the second, Sears was clearly outplayed,
and it went against him 6 to 2. The
last set went to deuce after Belt
had Sears 5 to 2. Then by cool
and consistent placing, Sears gradually pulled away and won 8 to 6.
Huck and Magoffin won from
Dubray and Crawford in the finals
of the doubles, 5 to 7, 6 to 3, 6 to
I. The defeat of the latter seemed
due to over confidence as much as
anything.
The consolations was carried off
by Marshall after defeating Gillet
in two close sets, 6 to 4, 6 to 4.
This Monday afternoon, at 3.30,
the finals of the singles will take
place at Homewood. The match
will be for the best three out of
five sets.
The prizes to be 'awarded are:
Singles—Cup, runner-up, gold;
doubles, two gold medals, runnersup, silver,; consolations, silver medal.

A SUMMER ENTERPRISE
Four Graduates to Spend Summer Dispensing the Learning They Have Acquired in the Past Four Years.

Hopkins has long been noted as
the home of research work, but it
has remained for Gorton, White,
Wolman, and Miller to make it
famous as the place where work is
done in searching for pupils. Several days ago a neat advertisement
appeared in the Baltimore papers announcing that a summer'school had
been started by four Hopkins graduates. It is supposed that as Mr.
"B. B." is .not on the staff of instructors, the school will be conducted like the student summer
schools of Princeton, Harvard, and
Yale. The trustees of the new
school have not selected a site upon
which to build dormitories and recitation halls; so for the present, the
professors will go to the pupils'
homes to teach. Perhaps even some
silent, shadowed grove in Druid
11 ill Park .will earn the name of
academe, and future generations
will say: "Here Gorton and his
disciples walked." The instructors
wish it understood that they are
highly specialized, possibly in the
geological sense.
Tt is not supposed that this new
summer school will injure the pros-

pects of Dr. Buchner's school; for
although the curriculum of the two
may be much alike, the modes of
instruction are diffgrent—the one
offers private instruction, the other,
instruction by class lectures. All
success to the new enterprise,'

John R. Mott—Mr. Mott is known
in practically every important student center in the world. He is
general secretary of the World's
Student Christian Federation, chairman of the Student Volunteer movement, and executive secretary of the
Foreign Department of the International Committee.
Roswell Bates—Mr. Bates is a
well known figure at many student
conferences. He has spoken here
at Hopkins and left an impression
upon every man who heard him.
The afternoons will be entirely
given to fellowship and sports, for
which there is abundant opportunity.
One of the features of the Conference is the struggle for the baseball
championship. In 1910, Hopkins
won at Pocono, defeating Princeton.
Last year Pennsylvania State College came out ahead. There is also
a track meet and an aquatic meet
which lend interest to the Conference in the rivalry among the delegations

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 27, 1912
Changes.

The close of the present academic
year will be marked by the passage
of several figures long well known
in Hopkins undergraduate life. Not
only will President Remsen's resignation take effect in June, and the
very highest office in the University
lose its present occupant, but when
the doors of the University open
next autumn, two other familiar
faces will be missed from McCoy
Hall. "Pa" Christhilf left three
weeks ago for California, and John
Holmes, after his marriage in June,
will depart for distant missionary
fields.
Mr. Holmes during his long connection with the University Y. M.
C. A. has come into contact with almost every man at Hopkins, and has
succeeded in winning universal confidence and esteem. This popularity4i
was attested by repeated unanimous,-'I
elections to the presidency of the
Athletic Association, and his efficiency and tact by the steady progress Which our athletics made under
his leadership. When the position
of graduate manager was instituted,
it was a matter of course that he
should be its first occupant; and in
that capacity he set a standard
which his successors will have to
work hard to equal. Mr. Holmes'
activities have not been confined to
one direction. He is remembered
as a ready speaker and a member
of several successful 'Varsity debating team. T-Iis work at the Y. M.
C. A, and the great change he has
brought about in the attitude of the
students toward it are matters of
coi,nmon knowledge. His place will
not be easy to fill; and THE NEWSLETTER wishes at the .same time to
express its regret at his departtge,

A Worthy Cause.

THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to say
a (r- ood word for the senior classbook. This little pamphlet, so lately
conceived and so unpretentious in
its aims, should revive the classbook tradition and make easier for
future classes the publication of
more stately volumes. Though comprising only about thirty pages, the
book will include everything worth
while that usually appears in a classbook—portraits, biographies, and
grinds of the seniors, the class history, the class poem, and the rest.
For the sake of class-spirit, if of
nothing else, the seniors should support it. Because of what it will do
in the way of reviving the classbook tradition, it is worthy of the
support of the underclassmen. The
argument that it may interfere with
the chances of future "Hullabaloos"
to procure advertisements, is at bottom nothing more than the argument that one year's class-book injures the prospects of this next
year's; and on this theory every
class should throw cold water on
the class-book projects of the
classes above it, and so no classbooks at all would be published.
.The argument is as groundless as
it would be to say .that today's
newspaper injures the advertising
chances of tomorrow's. THE NEWSLETTER has shown that it thinks the
little book a good thing by donating
its entire surplus to help defray the
expenses of its publication; it remains for the students to do the
rest.

To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER:
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
(THE NEWS-UTTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed with the name of the writer,
which, upon request, will be withheld.)

LYONS, May

12, 1912.

To the Editor of Tiit NE:NYS-LETTER :

Dear Sir—There appeared in one
of the local papers, today, an article
which may interest your readers
when once they recognize, beneath
the masquerade so kindly lent by
the "German professor" in question,
our good old "J. H. U." The translation follows:
"A German professor has visited
the universities of the four corners
of the earth to study the 'battle-cries'
of the students.
"In America alone he discovered
five hundred different 'howls.'
"At the Universite de Baltimore
they greet each other with:
"'Hullabaloo, canuck, canuck,
Hullabaloo!'
"At the Institut Polytechnique
d'Albania (sic):
"`Ki-yi-yi ! Ki-yi-yi! Hoop la hi !'
" "At the Universite de Kentucky:
"`Razzle, dazzle! Sisboom ! rah!
rah ! rah!'
"At the Facultee. Georgetown de
Washington:
"'Hoya! Loya! Sasca! Hoya!
Hoya!'"
"An I have omitted many of the
most harmonious!"
The learned German professor
has failed to draw his ethnological
conclusion from all of that: The
Americans are rapidly reverting to
the "habits of the 'red-skins.'"
Thus we live to learn! Although
this is not the first time that I have
seen criticisms on the same subject, these articles, are comparatively
rare. This is no doubt due to the
neglect accorded, in the Old World,
this important "branch of athletics."
Were it not for Fennimore Cooper
and a few athletic societies—one of
which recently created a small panic
at Paris with its yells—our "warcries" would he almost entirely t
known. In. the universities, owing'
to an absence of the class system,
they hold no place ; but judginofrom the great progress being, made
here in sports. I suppose that the
day is not far distant when such
"college-boy' demonstrations will be
only too widely spread.
Suggesting that you offer prizes
for the best solutions of the institutions of learning hidden above, and
wishing you the joy of hearing our
'by a
"harmonious" yells rendered'
foreign tongue, I am,
Sincerely yours,.
WALTER E. Aims,
Lecteur d'Anglais et la Faculte
des Lettres, Lyons, France.

Dear Sir—I should like to suggest that THE NEWSLETTER Board
offer a cash prize of one hundred
dollars to the first person who discovers what the following sentence
means:
"The end of all was to be a federation of South African States under
the British flag—the Cape Colony,
Natal, the Free State, the Transvaal,
Rhodesia, and because the Cape was
1,alf Boer, the Transvaal far balance
was to be made half British, while
the friendship of Natal and the
Free State might ease the working;
of the machine [what machine, Mahon, Padgett or Kelly's, or a locomobile1, and Rhodesia, English to
the backbone, should ensure the predominence of the Imperial element."
[In what.] Ladies and gentlemen,
• this is one of the three thousand
four hundred and twenty-three sentences contained in a book called
"The Growth of the Empire," written by an Englishman named Jose.
Members of the class in English
history will be examined on the
contents of this book in the coming
examinations.
All those who wish to compete
for the hundred-dollar prize should
have to deposit, before Wednesday,
at 5 o'clock in Box 9,999, an essay
of not more than five thousand
words, entitled: "What That Sentence Means."
The answers of the .contestants
could be turned over to the men in
History III on Thursday, so that
before they take their examinations,
they may be able to know the meaning of at least one sentence in their
text-book. The prize might then
be awarded as soon as a competent
judge could be selected. AMBAGES.

Every man connected with Hopkins who has not read the artiCle
on Robert Sampson Lanier on page
553 of the May Review of Reviews,
should not fail to do so before the
May magazines have been crowded
cut by the June ones. Our undergraduates, especially, should read
this article, as Robert Lanier is one
of the very few men who, after
graduating from the collegiate department, has done really significant
work in the world.
Robert Lanier was the third son
of Hopkins' "great poet and gentle
scholar," Sidney Lanier. He spent
his early years in Tryon, N. C.,
"where he grew in stature and
in wholesome knowledge without
school training'," _ When he was
nineteen years old he decided to
come to Hopkins, although at that
time he had a good position with
the McClure Company. He passed
the Hopkins entrance examination,
although he had never gone to
school. While here, he specialized
in history and political science, and
on account of the excellence of his
work, was elected to the Phi Beta
Kappa Society. In everything he
had shown an unquenchable sort of
ardor, and rare qualities of mind
and personality. A few years after
graduation, he became head of the
Review of Reviews' financial department, which undertook to advise
the ordinary investor how to make
safe investments. Robert Lanier
threw himself into the business of
writing letters to country school
teachers, or worried old ladies with
a chivalry and enthusiasm that
went far beyond any requirements

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 27, 1912.
MANAGER'S REPORT

TENNIS TEAM MAKES GOOD
Hopkins Players Break Even on
Very Successful Season—St.
John's Defeated.

Leland of Musical Clubs Submits Report of Finances During
Season 1911-12.

Manager

a

!

The excellent showing made by
the Johns Hopkins tennis team this
season should justify some action
on the part of the Board of Directors
of the Athletic Association to make
tennis one of the officially recognized
spring sports. A comprehensive
schedule of seven matches was arranged by Manager Donald K. Belt.
The long drawn out spell of bad
weather prevented three of them
from being played, and one was cancelled. The original schedule of
matches was as follows: Gettysburg,
Virginia Military Institute, St.
John's, Georgetown, University of
Virginia, Pennsylvania, and Haverford.
Gettysburg and Virginia Military
Institute could not be played on account of the rainy weather. Hopkins then opened its season with a
victory over St. John's. This match
was exceedingly hard fought and
close. Hopkins finally won after
an extra match had been played to
decide the tie, as each team won
two of the matches in the singles
and one in the doubles.
Hopkins then succeeded in tying
Georgetown the following Wednesday. The matches were not finished
.until so late that it was impossible
to decide the tie by an extra match.
One of the features of the Georgetown contest was the second set of
the Belt and Bacon, McLean and
Brosseau match. This was finally
lost by the Hopkins pair by the unusual score of 15 to 13.
Pennsylvania was the last opponent of Hopkins in tennis. The
Pennsylvania players have been
making a splendid record this year
against big college teams. The Hopkins players, therefore, felt greatly
pleased at winning two out of the
six matches.
Manager Belt succeeded in getting a number of candidates out for
the tennis team, and there would
have been even more who would
have tried for places on it if they had
not been engaged at the time in other
branches of athletics. Those who
played on the team in the three
matches were Donald K. Belt, Alfred C. Hat611, Albert L. Hammond,
Harry E. Corner, Arthur M. Bacon,
and Alfred Springer, Jr.
The spring tennis season is draw-/
ing to a close with one of the most
successful tournaments ever held at
Hopkins. The Homewood courts
will be used throughout the summer,
however, by the Hopkins students
and professors. Much credit for
the successful tournament and for
the tennis matches is due to Donald
K. Belt, who served as manager of
the tennis team and chairman of the
Tournament Committee.
Prospects for a successful tennis
season next year are very bright.
There are a number of good players
who will be back at the University,
and who intend to come out for the
team as soon as the call for candidates is issued next spring.

Cotrell 86 Leonard
ALBANY, N, Y.

Preparation was begun last week
to regrade the surface of Homewood 'Field. This will be the first
time the ground on the football
field has had a fresh layer of earth
since 1908. When the field was
originally built, the ends, which
were made ground taken from the
middle, were fixed about six inches
higher in order to allow for settling.
Strange to say, the ends refused to
settle, so in 1908 thirteen hundred
cartloads of dirt were piled on the
centre to build it .up even with the
ends.
Although the turf has received
constant attention in the four years
since then, the wear and tear of the
teams has completely used up the
grass. It is curious to learn that
the lacrosse team -harms the green
sward more than any other team,
even more than the football squad.
It is not because lacrosse is actually the hardest on the ground, but
rather because grass recovers better
during the winter than during the
summer.
It was decided that, as resurfacing had to be done, it might be
good to reo-rade a little also. The
plan it to raise the centre of the
field four inches, letting it slope
away on all sides, thus giving better
drainage. It is unfortunate that
this will prevent the seniors having
their exercises right on the field,
but it is realized that these few
weeks .coming between make the
difference between the use and nonuse of Homewood for next season's
football.

Combined Y. M. C. A. Student Conferences Will Meet This Year at Pennsylvania Resort, June 14 to 23.

The student conferences are regarded,everywhere as summing up
the year's work of the Student
Christian Associations of North
America. Every year increases the
number of college men who bear
witness to the value of these gatherings. In the interest of a larger
and more cosmopolitan gathering,
it has been decided to unite the Linwood Conference of Ohio and the
Pocono Conference of Pennsylvania.
The desirability of securing a more
satisfactory site has also helped to
determine this union. The new
gathering will he known as The
'Atlantic Student ConferMiddle'
ence, and will meet on the shores
of the beautiful Eagles-Mere Lake,
on the crest of the mountains north
of Williamsport, Pa., from June 14
to 23, 1912. No more desirable
o.r beautiful spot for a student conference could be desired. The lake
is a mile and a half long and one
mile wide, affording unsurpassed
opportunities for bathing on the
clean, evenly sloping white sand
beach and for most delightful rowing and canoeing.
The Student Conference is not a
purposeless outing. The forenoons
will be devoted to study of religious
and social conditions here and
abroad. The last period of each
forenoon will be the platform addresses, and a glance at the following list of speakers will convince
anyone of the strength and value
of the Eagles-Mere platform addresses. If there were nothing to
be gained from attending the conference but the privilege of hearing
these men, the conference would be
invaluable to every thinking collegeman. A partial list of those who
will address the conference is as follows:
Robert E. Speer—Mr. Speer is
a graduate of Princeton. He is
now secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian
Church. For many years he has
been a popular speaker at student
conferences in America, and his
journeys to other lands have made
him well known in some of the important student centers of the world.
Harry E. Fosdick—Mr. Fosdick
has been a popular speaker at summer conferences for some years, and
his invitations to fill college pulpits
have outrun the possibilities of acceptance. Those who were here
three years ago at Hopkins, remember what forceful addresses Mr.
Fosdick gave us.

After a week of hard matches,
the Hopkins Tennis Tournament is
completed, except for the last match
in the singles. In the finals, Sears,
an undergraduate, will fight it out
with Dubray, of the Medical School.
It is diffiC1.1-it to say who will win,
as the playing style of the two
players is directly opposite; while
Dubray is by far the more brilliant,
Sears plays a steady, persistent
game, which literally wears out an
opponent. Both players have had
to beat good men to get to the final
round. It took Dubrav three sets
to defeat both Getz and Crawford,
While Sears, in three of the four
matches he has played, namely,
those with Hatch, Huck, and Belt,
had to extend himself to three sets
also.
Sears' match with Belt in the
semi-finals Saturday afternoon was
desperately fought by both players.
The first set Belt lost 6 to 3, being
entirely off his game. In the second, Sears was clearly outplayed,
and it went against him 6 to 2. The
last set went to deuce after Belt
had Sears 5 to 2. Then by cool
and consistent placing, Sears gradually pulled away and won 8 to 6.
Huck and Magoffin won from
Dubray and Crawford in the finals
of the doubles, 5 to 7, 6 to 3, 6 to
I. The defeat of the latter seemed
due to over confidence as much as
anything.
The consolations was carried off
by Marshall after defeating Gillet
in two close sets, 6 to 4, 6 to 4.
This Monday afternoon, at 3.30,
the finals of the singles will take
place at Homewood. The match
will be for the best three out of
five sets.
The prizes to be 'awarded are:
Singles—Cup, runner-up, gold;
doubles, two gold medals, runnersup, silver,; consolations, silver medal.

A SUMMER ENTERPRISE
Four Graduates to Spend Summer Dispensing the Learning They Have Acquired in the Past Four Years.

Hopkins has long been noted as
the home of research work, but it
has remained for Gorton, White,
Wolman, and Miller to make it
famous as the place where work is
done in searching for pupils. Several days ago a neat advertisement
appeared in the Baltimore papers announcing that a summer'school had
been started by four Hopkins graduates. It is supposed that as Mr.
"B. B." is .not on the staff of instructors, the school will be conducted like the student summer
schools of Princeton, Harvard, and
Yale. The trustees of the new
school have not selected a site upon
which to build dormitories and recitation halls; so for the present, the
professors will go to the pupils'
homes to teach. Perhaps even some
silent, shadowed grove in Druid
11 ill Park .will earn the name of
academe, and future generations
will say: "Here Gorton and his
disciples walked." The instructors
wish it understood that they are
highly specialized, possibly in the
geological sense.
Tt is not supposed that this new
summer school will injure the pros-

pects of Dr. Buchner's school; for
although the curriculum of the two
may be much alike, the modes of
instruction are diffgrent—the one
offers private instruction, the other,
instruction by class lectures. All
success to the new enterprise,'

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 27, 1912
Changes.

The close of the present academic
year will be marked by the passage
of several figures long well known
in Hopkins undergraduate life. Not
only will President Remsen's resignation take effect in June, and the
very highest office in the University
lose its present occupant, but when
the doors of the University open
next autumn, two other familiar
faces will be missed from McCoy
Hall. "Pa" Christhilf left three
weeks ago for California, and John
Holmes, after his marriage in June,
will depart for distant missionary
fields.
Mr. Holmes during his long connection with the University Y. M.
C. A. has come into contact with almost every man at Hopkins, and has
succeeded in winning universal confidence and esteem. This popularity4i
was attested by repeated unanimous,-'I
elections to the presidency of the
Athletic Association, and his efficiency and tact by the steady progress Which our athletics made under
his leadership. When the position
of graduate manager was instituted,
it was a matter of course that he
should be its first occupant; and in
that capacity he set a standard
which his successors will have to
work hard to equal. Mr. Holmes'
activities have not been confined to
one direction. He is remembered
as a ready speaker and a member
of several successful 'Varsity debating team. T-Iis work at the Y. M.
C. A, and the great change he has
brought about in the attitude of the
students toward it are matters of
coi,nmon knowledge. His place will
not be easy to fill; and THE NEWSLETTER wishes at the .same time to
express its regret at his departtge,

A Worthy Cause.

THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to say
a (r- ood word for the senior classbook. This little pamphlet, so lately
conceived and so unpretentious in
its aims, should revive the classbook tradition and make easier for
future classes the publication of
more stately volumes. Though comprising only about thirty pages, the
book will include everything worth
while that usually appears in a classbook—portraits, biographies, and
grinds of the seniors, the class history, the class poem, and the rest.
For the sake of class-spirit, if of
nothing else, the seniors should support it. Because of what it will do
in the way of reviving the classbook tradition, it is worthy of the
support of the underclassmen. The
argument that it may interfere with
the chances of future "Hullabaloos"
to procure advertisements, is at bottom nothing more than the argument that one year's class-book injures the prospects of this next
year's; and on this theory every
class should throw cold water on
the class-book projects of the
classes above it, and so no classbooks at all would be published.
.The argument is as groundless as
it would be to say .that today's
newspaper injures the advertising
chances of tomorrow's. THE NEWSLETTER has shown that it thinks the
little book a good thing by donating
its entire surplus to help defray the
expenses of its publication; it remains for the students to do the
rest.

Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
(THE NEWS-UTTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.

LYONS, May

12, 1912.

To the Editor of Tiit NE:NYS-LETTER :

Dear Sir—There appeared in one
of the local papers, today, an article
which may interest your readers
when once they recognize, beneath
the masquerade so kindly lent by
the "German professor" in question,
our good old "J. H. U." The translation follows:
"A German professor has visited
the universities of the four corners
of the earth to study the 'battle-cries'
of the students.
"In America alone he discovered
five hundred different 'howls.'
"At the Universite de Baltimore
they greet each other with:
"'Hullabaloo, canuck, canuck,
Hullabaloo!'
"At the Institut Polytechnique
d'Albania (sic):
"`Ki-yi-yi ! Ki-yi-yi! Hoop la hi !'
" "At the Universite de Kentucky:
"`Razzle, dazzle! Sisboom ! rah!
rah ! rah!'
"At the Facultee. Georgetown de
Washington:
"'Hoya! Loya! Sasca! Hoya!
Hoya!'"
"An I have omitted many of the
most harmonious!"
The learned German professor
has failed to draw his ethnological
conclusion from all of that: The
Americans are rapidly reverting to
the "habits of the 'red-skins.'"
Thus we live to learn! Although
this is not the first time that I have
seen criticisms on the same subject, these articles, are comparatively
rare. This is no doubt due to the
neglect accorded, in the Old World,
this important "branch of athletics."
Were it not for Fennimore Cooper
and a few athletic societies—one of
which recently created a small panic
at Paris with its yells—our "warcries" would he almost entirely t
known. In. the universities, owing'
to an absence of the class system,
they hold no place ; but judginofrom the great progress being, made
here in sports. I suppose that the
day is not far distant when such
"college-boy' demonstrations will be
only too widely spread.
Suggesting that you offer prizes
for the best solutions of the institutions of learning hidden above, and
wishing you the joy of hearing our
'by a
"harmonious" yells rendered'
foreign tongue, I am,
Sincerely yours,.
WALTER E. Aims,
Lecteur d'Anglais et la Faculte
des Lettres, Lyons, France.

Dear Sir—I should like to suggest that THE NEWSLETTER Board
offer a cash prize of one hundred
dollars to the first person who discovers what the following sentence
means:
"The end of all was to be a federation of South African States under
the British flag—the Cape Colony,
Natal, the Free State, the Transvaal,
Rhodesia, and because the Cape was
1,alf Boer, the Transvaal far balance
was to be made half British, while
the friendship of Natal and the
Free State might ease the working;
of the machine [what machine, Mahon, Padgett or Kelly's, or a locomobile1, and Rhodesia, English to
the backbone, should ensure the predominence of the Imperial element."
[In what.] Ladies and gentlemen,
• this is one of the three thousand
four hundred and twenty-three sentences contained in a book called
"The Growth of the Empire," written by an Englishman named Jose.
Members of the class in English
history will be examined on the
contents of this book in the coming
examinations.
All those who wish to compete
for the hundred-dollar prize should
have to deposit, before Wednesday,
at 5 o'clock in Box 9,999, an essay
of not more than five thousand
words, entitled: "What That Sentence Means."
The answers of the .contestants
could be turned over to the men in
History III on Thursday, so that
before they take their examinations,
they may be able to know the meaning of at least one sentence in their
text-book. The prize might then
be awarded as soon as a competent
judge could be selected. AMBAGES.

Every man connected with Hopkins who has not read the artiCle
on Robert Sampson Lanier on page
553 of the May Review of Reviews,
should not fail to do so before the
May magazines have been crowded
cut by the June ones. Our undergraduates, especially, should read
this article, as Robert Lanier is one
of the very few men who, after
graduating from the collegiate department, has done really significant
work in the world.
Robert Lanier was the third son
of Hopkins' "great poet and gentle
scholar," Sidney Lanier. He spent
his early years in Tryon, N. C.,
"where he grew in stature and
in wholesome knowledge without
school training'," _ When he was
nineteen years old he decided to
come to Hopkins, although at that
time he had a good position with
the McClure Company. He passed
the Hopkins entrance examination,
although he had never gone to
school. While here, he specialized
in history and political science, and
on account of the excellence of his
work, was elected to the Phi Beta
Kappa Society. In everything he
had shown an unquenchable sort of
ardor, and rare qualities of mind
and personality. A few years after
graduation, he became head of the
Review of Reviews' financial department, which undertook to advise
the ordinary investor how to make
safe investments. Robert Lanier
threw himself into the business of
writing letters to country school
teachers, or worried old ladies with
a chivalry and enthusiasm that
went far beyond any requirements

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 27, 1912.
MANAGER'S REPORT

TENNIS TEAM MAKES GOOD
Hopkins Players Break Even on
Very Successful Season—St.
John's Defeated.

Leland of Musical Clubs Submits Report of Finances During
Season 1911-12.

Manager

a

!

The excellent showing made by
the Johns Hopkins tennis team this
season should justify some action
on the part of the Board of Directors
of the Athletic Association to make
tennis one of the officially recognized
spring sports. A comprehensive
schedule of seven matches was arranged by Manager Donald K. Belt.
The long drawn out spell of bad
weather prevented three of them
from being played, and one was cancelled. The original schedule of
matches was as follows: Gettysburg,
Virginia Military Institute, St.
John's, Georgetown, University of
Virginia, Pennsylvania, and Haverford.
Gettysburg and Virginia Military
Institute could not be played on account of the rainy weather. Hopkins then opened its season with a
victory over St. John's. This match
was exceedingly hard fought and
close. Hopkins finally won after
an extra match had been played to
decide the tie, as each team won
two of the matches in the singles
and one in the doubles.
Hopkins then succeeded in tying
Georgetown the following Wednesday. The matches were not finished
.until so late that it was impossible
to decide the tie by an extra match.
One of the features of the Georgetown contest was the second set of
the Belt and Bacon, McLean and
Brosseau match. This was finally
lost by the Hopkins pair by the unusual score of 15 to 13.
Pennsylvania was the last opponent of Hopkins in tennis. The
Pennsylvania players have been
making a splendid record this year
against big college teams. The Hopkins players, therefore, felt greatly
pleased at winning two out of the
six matches.
Manager Belt succeeded in getting a number of candidates out for
the tennis team, and there would
have been even more who would
have tried for places on it if they had
not been engaged at the time in other
branches of athletics. Those who
played on the team in the three
matches were Donald K. Belt, Alfred C. Hat611, Albert L. Hammond,
Harry E. Corner, Arthur M. Bacon,
and Alfred Springer, Jr.
The spring tennis season is draw-/
ing to a close with one of the most
successful tournaments ever held at
Hopkins. The Homewood courts
will be used throughout the summer,
however, by the Hopkins students
and professors. Much credit for
the successful tournament and for
the tennis matches is due to Donald
K. Belt, who served as manager of
the tennis team and chairman of the
Tournament Committee.
Prospects for a successful tennis
season next year are very bright.
There are a number of good players
who will be back at the University,
and who intend to come out for the
team as soon as the call for candidates is issued next spring.

Preparation was begun last week
to regrade the surface of Homewood 'Field. This will be the first
time the ground on the football
field has had a fresh layer of earth
since 1908. When the field was
originally built, the ends, which
were made ground taken from the
middle, were fixed about six inches
higher in order to allow for settling.
Strange to say, the ends refused to
settle, so in 1908 thirteen hundred
cartloads of dirt were piled on the
centre to build it .up even with the
ends.
Although the turf has received
constant attention in the four years
since then, the wear and tear of the
teams has completely used up the
grass. It is curious to learn that
the lacrosse team -harms the green
sward more than any other team,
even more than the football squad.
It is not because lacrosse is actually the hardest on the ground, but
rather because grass recovers better
during the winter than during the
summer.
It was decided that, as resurfacing had to be done, it might be
good to reo-rade a little also. The
plan it to raise the centre of the
field four inches, letting it slope
away on all sides, thus giving better
drainage. It is unfortunate that
this will prevent the seniors having
their exercises right on the field,
but it is realized that these few
weeks .coming between make the
difference between the use and nonuse of Homewood for next season's
football.
Dr. Spieker Honored.
